fields.fabDescription: Cotton is a cellulosic fiber obtained from the seed of a cotton plant Depending on the fiber length and/or finish, fabrics can have a matte or lustrous appearance Photomicrographs courtesy of Agricultural Research Service, US Dept. of Agriculture

Fiber is taken from the stem and root of the flax plant Fabrics made from flax are referred to as linen fabrics Strong, stiff fiber Poor resiliency Photomicrographs courtesy of British Textiles Technology Group
Flax is a cellulosic fiber taken from the stem and root of the flax plant Fabrics made from flax are referred to as linen fabrics Strong, stiff fiber Poor resiliency

Retting - loosening the fibers for easy removal from the stalk Scutching - removing the woody portion of the stalks by passing them between metal fluted rollers Hackling - combing the fibers to remove the irregular and short fibers
Twine yarn made from flax
Carpet made from flax
Linen fabrics are good for warm weather garments due to high heat conduction of the flax fibers

Cellulosic fiber also known as grasscloth or China grass Long fibers create a high luster Strongest natural fiber Used in apparel and home furnishing fabrics Photomicrographs courtesy of British Textiles Technology Group
Ramie fiber after being harvested and cleaned
Cellulosic fiber also known as grasscloth or China grass Long fibers create a high luster Strongest natural fiber High absorbency  Moderate thermal retention
Cellulosic fiber Stiffer and coarser than flax Good absorbency and high strength Used for ropes, thread, apparel and home furnishings Photomicrographs courtesy of British Textiles Technology Group
Cellulosic fiber Stiffer and coarser than flax Good absorbency and comfort High strength Used for ropes, thread, apparel and home furnishings
A heavy weight plain weave fabric made of hemp
Cellulosic fiber Poor strength due to short brittle fiber bundles Inexpensive fiber Used in carpet backings, coffee and sugar bags, ropes, and home furnishings
Cellulosic fiber Poor strength due to short brittle fiber bundles Inexpensive fiber
Carpet backing made of jute fiber
Cellulosic fiber from the sisal plant Used for ropes, brush bristles, carpets and upholstery fabrics
This is a rug made from sisal fiber

A protein fiber obtained from the fleece of sheep Thermal retentive due to the layer of air trapped in the center of the fibers High resiliency Photomicrographs courtesy of DWI-Deutsches Wollforschungsinstitut/Franz-J.Wortmann and IWTO

Protein fiber from silkworm cocoons Only natural fiber available in filament and staple form  Does not shrink Wide range of apparel and home furnishing fabrics Used in the medical field for prosthetic arteries and sutures Moderate resiliency
Cocoons created by silkworms
Protein fiber from wild silkworm cocoons Spun silk fiber Does not shrink Wide range of apparel and home furnishing fabrics Moderate resiliency
Protein fiber from wild silkworm cocoons Spun silk fiber Does not shrink Wide range of apparel and home furnishing fabrics Moderate resiliency

Duppioni silk is created by two silkworms spinning their cocoons together Produces thick-and-thin yarns larger than regular silk filament Does not shrink Often used in shantung fabrics Moderate resiliency
Characterized by fine filament silk yarns

First synthetic fiber produced in the United States Excellent durability and abrasion resistance High appearance retention Used in tire cords, car interiors, ropes and industrial fabrics Used in apparel for sportswear, hosiery and lingerie
A nylon warp knit  Stiff durable fabric Used for industrial products
A filament yarn nylon fabric

Most widely used synthetic fiber in the United States Used abundantly in various types of apparel and home furnishing fabrics Also used for fiberfill, tire cords, nonwoven fabrics and many industrial products
A microfiber is a fiber with a denier of less than 1

Produced using recycled soda bottles

High durability and abrasion resistance  High chemical resistance Low absorbency Excellent wicking characteristics Used in car interiors, carpeting, socks, sweaters and sportswear
Olefin fabrics are durable and strong Excellent abrasion resistance
A coated upholstery fabric made of olefin

Wool-like aesthetics Moisture is wicked away from the skin to the surface of the fiber instead of being absorbed Used mainly in apparel fabrics such as sweaters, fleece fabrics, furs for coats and stuffed animals

Wool-like aesthetics Moisture is wicked away from the skin to the surface of the fiber instead of being absorbed Used mainly in apparel fabrics such as sweaters, fleece fabrics, furs for coats and stuffed animals

Flame retardant fiber Characteristics similar to acrylic Soft, warm and resilient fiber Pills more quickly than acrylic Used in fake furs, wigs, outdoor fabrics, protective clothing and home furnishing fabrics
Flame retardant fiber Characteristics similar to acrylic Soft, warm and resilient fiber Pills more quickly than acrylic Used in home furnishing fabrics
Low/moderate durability Soft and comfortable fiber Low resiliency Used in apparel, drapery/upholstery and nonwoven fabrics
Low/moderate durability Soft and comfortable fiber Low resiliency Used in apparel, drapery, upholstery and nonwoven fabrics
Regenerated from raw bamboo pulp Soft hand and comfortable Good wicking characteristics Used in apparel, towels, and sheets
Regenerated from raw bamboo pulp Soft hand and comfortable Good wicking characteristics Used in apparel, towels, and sheets

Aesthetics vary depending on the fiber length, luster and diameter Performs like cotton but has much higher resiliency High thermal conductivity Soft and comfortable  Used in apparel and home furnishings
Aesthetics vary depending on the fiber length, luster and diameter Performs like cotton High thermal conductivity Soft and comfortable  Used in apparel and home furnishings

A manufactured cellulosic fiber High luster Excellent drape Poor resistance to abrasion Poor wrinkle resistance  Used in formalwear, drapery fabrics, bedding fabrics, lining fabrics and cigarette filters
High luster and excellent drape Poor resistance to abrasion and poor wrinkle resistance  Low cost fiber The video shows an acetate yarn dissolving in acetone nail polish remover

Rubber can be natural or synthetic Excellent elastic recovery Spandex has replaced rubber in many applications Synthetic rubber is widely used in narrow elastic fabrics

Spandex is typically not used alone in fabrics It does not deteriorate as quickly as rubber  Foundation garments containing spandex are lighter weight than those made of rubber Excellent elastic recovery

High tenacity Resistant to high temperatures Used in protective clothing such as bullet-proof vests, firefighter uniforms and suits for racecar drivers Commonly used in boats, airplanes and aerospace products

High tenacity Resistant to high temperatures Used in protective clothing such as bullet-proof vests, firefighter uniforms and suits for racecar drivers Commonly used in boats, airplanes and aerospace products
Outstanding flame resistance The yarns carbonize instead of melting, burning or fusing when exposed to flames Used in protective clothing and industrial products

High tenacity Resistant to high temperatures Used in protective clothing such as bullet-proof vests, firefighter uniforms and suits for racecar drivers Commonly used in boats, airplanes and aerospace products
High tenacity Resistant to high temperatures

Incombustible fiber Used in flame retardant draperies, mattress covers, building insulation, geotextiles and industrial products Not used in apparel due to skin abrasion from broken glass fiber particles
This is an industrial fabric made of glass fiber Can withstand very high temperatures Used in products where high heat resistance is important

This is a commercial drapery casement fabric made of glass fiber. Flame retardant polyester casements and sheers, due to their easy care and other features, are more widely used in the marketplace than glass casements.
Resistant to weather Used in agricultural protective fabrics, home furnishings, films, lawn chair webbing and plastics

Flame retardant fiber Commonly used for wigs, Christmas trees, protective clothing and industrial purposes
Characterized by staple fibers that are spun together to form a yarn
Characterized by staple fibers that are spun together to form a yarn
Made up of very lengthy (filament) fibers All filament fibers are manufactured, with silk filament being the exception
Made up of very lengthy (filament) fibers Filaments create a luster on the surface of the fabric
Chemicals, heat or high velocity air are applied to produce texture in the yarn
Chemicals, heat or high velocity air are applied to produce texture in the yarn
Mono meaning "one", these yarns consist of one filament fiber Typically used as fishing line, sewing thread, etc.
Polypropylene solution that has been extruded as a film Used in nets, rope, carpet backing and cords
Polypropylene solution that has been extruded as a film This fabric is a carpet backing
Characterized by a single twisted strand
Characterized by two single yarns twisted together
This fabric contains ply yarns
Characterized by two or more ply yarns that are twisted together to form one yarn
A novelty/fancy yarn created by specks of short, various colored fibers twisted into the yarn
Tweed is characterized by novelty/fancy tweed yarns
A novelty/fancy yarn distinguished by its slubs or thick and thin segments
Distinguished by yarns that have slubs or thick and thin segments at random intervals The slubs create texture in the fabric
A novelty/fancy yarn that is wavy with an occasional loop effect

Bouclé loop yarns are used to achieve a looped pile effect
A novelty/fancy yarn containing one or more metal fibers
The metallic yarns in this brocade give the fabric a luster  Frequently used for eveningwear
Distinguished by pile on either one side or both sides Yarns are pieces cut from a woven fabric and fringed to create a pile novelty/fancy yarn

The pile in the fabric was created by the chenille yarns Used for apparel

Fabric Name: 	Ninon Fiber Content: 	100% Polyester Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Piece Dyed Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by unevenly spaced filament yarns  Warp yarns are grouped in pairs  Often used in sheer curtains and draperies

Fabric Name: 	Ninon Fiber Content: 	100% Polyester Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Resist Print/Screen Method Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by unevenly spaced filament yarns  Warp yarns are grouped in pairs  Often used in sheer curtains and draperies

Fabric Name: 	Georgette Fiber Content: 	100% Polyester Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Resist Print/Screen Method Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by crepe twist filament yarns with alternating S and Z twist, giving the fabric a less smooth appearance than chiffon  Excellent drape  Used for formalwear, blouses, dresses and lingerie

Fabric Name: 	Chiffon Fiber Content: 	100% Polyester Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Resist Print/Screen Method Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by small, highly twisted crepe yarns which give the fabric excellent drape  Smoother and more lustrous than georgette  Used for formalwear, nightwear, blouses, dresses and lingerie

Fabric Name: 	Voile Fiber Content: 	65% Polyester/35% Cotton Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Piece Dyed (Union) Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by highly twisted spun yarns which give the fabric a stiff hand  Typically a lower yarn count than chiffon  Used in sheer curtains

Fabric Name: 	Organdy Fiber Content: 	100% Cotton Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	N/A Finish: 	Acid Finish/Parchmentized/Bleached Miscellaneous Information: 	 Cotton fabric distinguished by its sheerness and crispness which are a result of an acid finish on combed cotton yarns  Used in curtains and as a stiffening fabric for formalwear

Fabric Name: 	Organza Fiber Content: 	100% Silk Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Piece Dyed Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by its body and crisp hand which are a result of highly twisted filament yarns  Used for formalwear, millinery and curtains

Fabric Name: 	Organza Fiber Content: 	100% Polyester Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Piece Dyed Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by its body and crisp hand which are a result of highly twisted filament yarns  Used for formalwear, millinery and curtains

Fabric Name: 	Lawn Cloth Fiber Content: 	100% Cotton Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Resist Print/Screen Method Finish: 	N/A Miscellaneous Information: 	 Lightweight but not transparent  Often cotton or a cotton/polyester blend  Used in apparel

Fabric Name: 	Batiste Fiber Content: 	100% Cotton Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Piece Dyed Finish: 	Mercerized Miscellaneous Information: 	 Distinguished by its soft hand  Used for blouses, dresses and curtains

Fabric Name: 	Nainsook Fiber Content: 	100% Cotton Construction Method: 	Balanced Plain Weave Dye/Print Method: 	Piece Dyed Finish: 	Mercerized Miscellaneous Information: 	 Lightweight fabric similar to batiste Used in children's garments, lingerie and blouses

fields.description: Banana fiber is a natural bast fiber. It has its own physical and chemical characteristics and many other properties that make it a fine quality fiber.Small pieces of these trunks are put through a softening process for mechanical extraction of the fibers, and then bleaching, and drying. The fiber obtained thus has appearance similar to silk which has become popular as banana silk fiber yarn.

Cashmere is characterized by its fine, soft fibers. It provides a natural light-weight insulation without bulk. Fibers are highly adaptable and easily spun into yarns and light to heavy-weight fabrics. The original undyed or natural colors of cashmere wool are various shades of grey, brown and white.
Contact us for color choices or for ordering pounds! ($40/lb)
Contact us for color choices and for ordering pounds! ($45/lb)  Merino wool is finely crimped and soft. Staples are commonly 65 – 100 mm (2.5 - 4 inches) long.

The nettle plant is found naturally in the wild in remote mountainous areas. The fibers are processed and spun by hand. The resulting yarn has a natural and rustic appeal. Nettle yarn has a texture similar to natural linen and like linen will soften with wear. Nettle is a natural moth repellent and is often used in Nepal for backing wool carpets.

SeaCell®pure is a cellulose fiber containing seaweed (e.g. ascophyllum nodosum). The idea behind SeaCell®pure is actually quite simple: The natural raw materials cellulose and seaweed represent the basis for the manufacture of the SeaCell®pure fiber, employing the "Lyocell Process". The cellulose fibers act as functional substrate for the seaweed
A manufactured fiber in which the fiberforming substance is composed of any regenerated, naturally occurring soybean protein.

Students can learn the basics of felting with our latest product, The Felting Kit!   The Felting Kit will encourage students’ creativity in a unique way by creating usable and wearable works of art!   Felting is a skill that can be enjoyed for many years!   10 Felting Assignments Uniquely Felt by Christine White** Easy to Follow Instructions All Needed Materials for Felting Wool Fiber Provided for Each Assignment Images of Assignments Provided to Students Images & Videos Provided to Instructors Complimentary Scarf for a Bonus Assignment Additional Images of Felted Examples   ISBN: 978-1-936480-01-2 *Complimentary instructor kit with orders of 10+     The Felting Kit includes   1.	Plastic tote 2.	Wooden dowel 3.	Bubble packaging squares (2) 4.	White chiffon fabric 5.	Waterproof apron 6.	Measuring tape 7.	Rubber bands for wooden dowel (4) 8.	Pin back and leather sample (2) 9.	Bonus silk scarf 10.	Glass beads and small rubber bands (5) 11.	Soap 12.	Wool roving (11 bags) 13.	Small plastic bowl 14.	Uniquely Felt textbook   *"Textbook is provided for supplemental reading and additional knowledge of felting. Assignments in The Felting Kit are not found in Uniquely Felt.

The Fiber Samples Packet contains 25 different fibers and a burn test chart.  Fox Fibre Cotton Flax Ramie Hemp Silk Wool Mohair Alpaca Angora Yak Camel's Hair Rayon Acetate Lyocell Nylon Polyester Olefin Acrylic Modacrylic Spandex Aramid Glass Vinyon PLA/Ingeo™

123 - 2.5" Warp x 2" Filling Apparel and Interior Fabric Swatches 16 Fiber clusters representing all fiber classifications (for classroom orders fibers are sent to instructor for distribution) 21 Yarn Lengths representing various classes and constructions (for classrooms orders yarns are sent to instructor for distribution) Lab Manual complete with identification guidelines and mounting sheets organized in the the following Six Exercises: Textile Structure Identification Fiber Identification Yarn Identification Fabric Construction Identification Colored Fabric Identification Finish Identification Students are challenged to discover the identity of the items in the collection because the specific names/identities are not revealed Corresponds directly to Textile Science by Kathryn Hatch

The High School Textile Swatch Kit was designed exclusively for high school level fashion and interior design courses. This kit was developed from feedback of our recent survey taken by high school educators.  48 4" Warp x 3" Filling Apparel and Interior Fabric Swatches Mounting Sheets Master List (includes fabric name, description and fiber content) Three Ring Binder for Organization *Complimentary Instructor Swatch Kit with a classroom order of swatch kits.*  Instructor Swatch Kit Includes: Student Swatch Kit Manual Containing Detailed Information Including: Yarn Type Fabric Description Dye/Print Method Finish Color Guide and Yarn Count Suggested End Uses
